explanations: The French text expresses a personal contentment and modesty ('Me voilà fort en repos... Je suis bien aise... Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément...'), with a tone of satisfaction with Earth's situation and a gentle, repeated emphasis. The English simplifies and sharpens this to 'no fear of being over-run by Jupiter' and omits the repetition and the mood of modest self-restraint, introducing a defensive nuance ('over-run') absent from the original.

The French states 'ces quatre Lune vous y donnent les plus jolis Spectacles du monde' emphasizing that wherever you are on Jupiter, the four moons provide the loveliest sights in the world. The English translation weakens the universality and continuous nature, with 'sometimes the prettiest sight imaginable,' making it sound occasional and more subjective, thus toning down the marvel suggested in the French.

The French highlights the perpetual eclipses, noting 'il ne se passe point de jour qu'elles ne s'éclipsent les unes les autres, ou qu'elles n'éclipsent le Soleil,' and that eclipses are a matter of amusement rather than fear, 'elles y sont un sujet de divertissement, & non pas de frayeur, comme en celui-ci.' The translation turns the interest in eclipses into 'Oh, how I should love to see this pleasant sport of Eclipses,' foregrounding the narrator's personal desire and omits the explicit comparison to Earth's fearful response to eclipses, modifying the tone from universal observation to personal curiosity and losing the Enlightenment critique of superstition.

The French original alludes to the 'jeu perpétuel d'Eclipses' as a source of an ongoing, collective amusement and concludes with 'le feu Duc de B-m dans sa Répétition, a tiré la danse des éclipses de cette Planète, comme maintenant la plupart de nos danses à la mode viennent de France,' referencing contemporary fashionable practices. The translation 'the late Duke of B-m in his Rehersal, brought the dance of Eclipses from that Planet, as now most of our modish Dances come out of France' omits the subtlety of the satire against French influence and the playful connection to perpetual celestial movement, reducing satire to a straightforward contemporary reference.

chunks.source_manual: <P070>Et vous ne manquerez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, à faire habiter ces quatre Lunes, quoy que ce ne foient que de petites Planetes subalternes, destinées seulement à en éclairer une autre pendant ces nuits? N'en doutez nullement, répondis-je. Ces Planees n'en sont pas moins dignes d'être habitées pour avoir le malheur d'être asservies à tourner autour d'une autre plus importante.</P070> <P071>Je voudrais donc, reprit-elle, que les Habitans des quatre Lunes de Jupiter <UP></UP>, fussont donc toûjours cette monstrueuse Planete sûspedüe sur leurs têtes à une distance assez petite. En verité, si les Gaulois craignaient anciennement que le ciel ne tombât sur eux, les Habitans de cette Lune auroient bien plus de sujet de craindre une chute de Jupiter <UP></UP>. C'est peut-être là aussi la frayeur qu'ils ont, dit- elle, au lieu de celle des Eclipses, dont vous m'avez assurée qu'ils sont exempts, & qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise? Il le faut de necessité absolue, répondis-je. L'inventeur du troisième Système dont je vous parlois l'autre jour, le celebre Tycho Brahé <UP></UP>, un des plus grands Astronomes qui furent jamais, n'avoit garde de craindre les Eclipses, comme le Vulgaire les craint, il passoit sa vie avec elles. Mais croiriez-vous bien ce qu'il craignoit en leur place? Si en sortant de son logis la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit êtoit une Vieille, si un Lievre traversoit son chemin, Tycho Brahé croyoit que la journée devoit être malheureuse, & retournoit promptement se renfermer chez luy, sans oser commencer la moindre chose.</P071>
chunks.target_manual: <P056>Well, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I hope you will People these four Moons, tho' you say they are but little secondary Planets, appointed to give light to another Planet during its Night. Do not doubt it, I reply'd; these Planets are not a jot the worse to be inhabited, for being forc'd to turn round another Planet of greater consequence. I would have then, says she, the People of these four Moons, to be so many Colonies under Jupiter's <UP>Government</UP>; they should receive their Laws and Customs from him. Would it not be convenient too, said I, that they should send Deputies with Addresses to him; for he hath cetainly a more absolute command over his Moon, than we have over ours; tho' his Power <UP>after all, is but imaginary</UP>, and consists chiefly in making 'em afraid; for that Moon which is nearest to him, sees that he is <UP>three hundred and sixty times bigger than our Moon appears to us</UP>; for in truth, he is so much bigger than she; he is also much nearer to them, than our Moon is to us, the which makes him appear the greater, so that this <UP>formidable</UP> Planet hangs continually over their Heads, at a very little distance and if the Gauls were afraid heretofore that the Heavens would fall on 'em, I think the Inhabitants of that Moon may well be apprehensive that Jupiter will at some time or other overwhelm 'em. They are, says she, I fancy, possess'd with that fear, because they are not concern'd at Eclipses: Every one has their due folly; we are afraid of an Eclipse, and they, that Jupiter will fall on their Heads. It is very true, said I, the Inventer of the third Systeme, I told you t'other night, the famous Ticho Brahe, <NCP>(one of the greatest Astronomers that ever was,)</NCP> <UP>did not apprehend the least danger from an Eclipse, when every body else was under the greatest consternation; yet this great Man had as an unaccountable a fear, did a hare cross him, or were the first Person he met in a morning an old Woman, home presently went Ticho Brahe, he shut himself up for that day, and would not meddle with the least Business</UP>.</P056>

explanations: While the French emphasizes the moons' status as 'de petites Planetes subalternes, destinées seulement à en éclairer une autre', the translation omits the nuance of 'subordinate' (subalternes) and their 'destined only' purpose, instead using a neutral 'secondary Planets, appointed to give light'. The connotation of subordination and limitation is softened, so the moons appear less insignificant and more functional.

The original French has the inhabitants always seeing 'cette monstrueuse Planete sûspedüe sur leurs têtes', focusing on a perpetual visual impression and threat, whereas the translation completely rewrites this: 'the People ... to be so many Colonies under Jupiter's Government; they should receive their Laws and Customs from him.' This not only omits the imagery of the looming planet, but introduces the concept of 'colonies', 'government', 'laws and customs', a socio-political metaphor which is absent in the original—altering the tone and perceivable implications entirely.

The French sets up a direct comparison of fear with 'les Habitans de cette Lune auroient bien plus de sujet de craindre une chute de Jupiter', stressing rational comparison of danger, but the English softens to 'may well be apprehensive that Jupiter will ... overwhelm 'em,' changing the notion of 'subject for fear' to a vaguer, less direct apprehension, diminishing the directness of the threat and the rational basis for fear that is made explicit in the French.

The translator renders 'la frayeur qu'ils ont ... au lieu de celle des Eclipses ... & qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise?' as 'They are ... possess'd with that fear, because they are not concern'd at Eclipses: Every one has their due folly; we are afraid of an Eclipse, and they, that Jupiter will fall on their Heads.' The English generalizes with 'every one has their due folly', splitting the parallel, while the French pointedly calls their new fear a 'sottise', highlighting universal human irrationality more sharply, and losing the satirical undertone present in the French.

The French, 'Mais croiriez-vous bien ce qu'il craignoit en leur place? Si en sortant de son logis la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit êtoit une Vieille, si un Lievre traversoit son chemin,' carries the structure of 'would you believe what he feared instead? If when leaving home the first person he met was an old woman, or if a hare crossed his path ...' with a sense of incredulity and context of replacing one superstition with another. The English collapses this to a flat list, omitting the rhetorical question and the contrast with what others fear, thus losing the ironic presentation and shifting the expressive register toward a factual anecdote.

chunks.source_manual: <P072>Il ne seroit pas juste, reprit- <IIM>elle</IIM>, après que cet homme-là n'a pû se delivrer impunément de la, que les Habitans de cette <UP></UP> Lune de Jupiter, dont nous parlions, en fussent quittes à meilleur marché. Nous ne leur ferons pas de quartier, ils subiront la Loy commune <UP></UP>, & donneront dans quelque autre erreur, mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner, éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques moments. Si la Terre est si petite à l'égard de Jupiter, Jupiter nous voit-il? Je crains que nous ne luy soyons inconnus.</P072> <P073>De bonne foy, je croy que cela est, répondis-je. Il faudroit qu'il vît la Terre quatre-vingt-dix fois plus petite que nous ne le voyons. C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point. Voicy seulement ce que nous pouvons croire de meilleur pour nous. Il y aura dans Jupiter des Astronomes, qui aprés avoir bien pris de la peine à composer des Lunettes excellentes, aprés avoir choisy les plus belles Nuits pour observer, auront enfin découvert dans les Cieux une petite Planete qu'ils n'avoient jamais veüe. D'abord le <NCE>Journal des Savants</NCE> de ce Pays-là en parle; le Peuple de Jupiter, ou n'en entend point parler, ou n'en fait que rire. Les Philosophes dont cela détruit les opinions, forment le dessein de n'en rien croire, il n'y a que les Gens tres raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter. On observe encore, on revoit la petite Planete, on s'assure bien que ce n'est point une vision; on commence même à soupçonner qu'elle a un mouvement autour du Soleil; on trouve au bout de mille observations, que ce <RW>mouvement</RW> est d'une année; & enfin, grâce à toutes les peines que se donnent les Savats, <NCP></NCP> on sait dans Jupiter que notre Terre est un Monde. Les Lurieux vont la voir au bout d'une Lunette, & la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper.</P073>
chunks.target_manual: <P057>Let us go on with ours tho', says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, and leave Ticho Brahe to defend his Superstition. Pray tell me, if the Earth be so little in comparison of Jupiter, whether his Inhabitants do discover us? Indeed, said I, I believe not; for if we appear to him ninety times less than he appears to us; judge you if there be any possibility: Yet this we may reasonably conjecture, that there are Astronomers in Jupiter, that after they have made the most curious Telescopes, and taken the clearest Night for their observations, they may have discover'd a little Planet in the Heavens, which they never saw before; if they publish their discovery, most People know not what they mean, or laugh at 'em for Fools; nay, the Philosophers themselves will not believe 'em, for fear of destroying their own opinions; yet some few may be a little curious; they continue their observations, discover the little Planet again, and are now assur'd it is no Vision; then they conclude it hath a motion round the Sun, which it compleats in a year, and at last, <NCP>(thanks to the Learned,)</NCP> they know in Jupiter our Earth is a World, every body runs to see it at the end of the Telescope, tho' 'tis so little, 'tis hardly discover'd.</P057>

Le Peuple de Jupiter, ou n'en entend point parler, ou n'en fait que rire. Les Philosophes dont cela détruit les opinions, forment le dessein de n'en rien croire, il n'y a que les Gens tres raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter.
target_segments: Let us go on with ours tho', says the Countess, and leave Ticho Brahe to defend his Superstition. Pray tell me, if the Earth be so little in comparison of Jupiter, whether his Inhabitants do discover us?

if they publish their discovery, most People know not what they mean, or laugh at 'em for Fools; nay, the Philosophers themselves will not believe 'em, for fear of destroying their own opinions; yet some few may be a little curious;
explanations: The entire opening segment in the French reflects the Marquise's witty continuation of a previous analogy involving the inhabitants of Jupiter's moon deserving 'no quarter'—they should be as fallible as people elsewhere. This element is omitted and replaced with a generic 'let us go on with ours,' and a reference to Tycho Brahe that does not appear in the source. This erases the playful tone and the satirical social commentary about human error, which was part of Fontenelle's Enlightenment subtle critique.

The French specifies that the people of Jupiter 'either do not hear of it or only laugh at it,' and that 'philosophers whose opinions are destroyed by this discovery resolve to not believe it, and only the most reasonable people willingly consent to doubt.' The translation simplifies and manipulates this by having people 'laugh at 'em for Fools' and philosophers not believing out of fear, and changes the group described as 'the most reasonable people who are willing to doubt' into 'some few may be a little curious,' which shifts the meaning from intellectual humility to mere curiosity.

chunks.source_manual: <P074>Si ce n'êtoit, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qu'il n'est point trop agreable de savoir qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, je me représenterois avec plaisir ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nôtres le sont vers luy, & cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considèrent & demandent l'une de l'autre, Quel monde est-ce là? Quelles gens l'habitent?</P074> <P075><IIM>Cela ne va pas si vite que vous pensez</IIM>, répliquay-je. Quand on verroit nôtre Terre de dedans Jupiter, quand on l'y connoîtroit, nôtre Terre ce n'est pas nous; on n'a pas le moindre soupçon qu'elle puisse être habitée. Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer, Dieu sait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy. Peut-être même sommes-nous cause qu'on y <UP>a fait le procés</UP> à des Philosophes qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous êtions. Cependant je croirois plus volontiers que les Habitans de Jupiter sont assez occupez à faire des découvertes sur leur Planete, pour ne songer point du tout à nous. Elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, assurément <UP>leurs Christophe Colombs ne sauroient manquer d'employ</UP>. Il faut que les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples, au lieu que dans Mercure, <NCP>qui est fort petit</NCP>, ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble, & ne comptent que pour une promenade de faire le tour de leur Monde. Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter, vous jugez bien qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure, qui sont des Mondes, & plus petits, & plus éloignez de luy. En récompense ses Habitans voyent Mars, & leurs quatre Lunes, & Saturne <RW>avec les siennes</RW>. Voilà assez de Planetes pour embarrasser ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes; la Nature a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers.</P075> <P076>Quoy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous comptez cela pour une grâce? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand <RW>Tourbillon</RW> seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres qui avoient êté cachées; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.</P076>
chunks.target_manual: <P058>It must be pleasant, says she, to see the Astronomers of both Planets, levelling their Tubes at one another, like two files of Musqueteers, and mutually asking, What World is that? What People inhabit it? Not so fast neither, I reply'd, for tho' they may from Jupiter discover our Earth, yet they may not know us; that is, they may not have the least suspicion it is inhabited; and should any one there chance to have such a fancy, he might be sufficiently ridicul'd, if not prosecuted for it; for my part, I believe they have work enough to make discoveries on their own Planet, not to trouble their Heads with ours; <UP>and had Sir Francis Drake and Columbus been in Jupiter, they might have had good employments</UP>; why, I warrant you, they have not yet discover'd the hundredth part of their Planet; when Mercury is so little, they are all <NCP>(as it were)</NCP> near Neighbours, and 'tis but taking a walk, to go round that Planet. But if we do not appear to 'em in Jupiter, they cannot certainly discover Venus and Mercury, which are much less than the Earth, and at a greater distance; but in lieu of it, they see Mars, their own four Moons, and Saturn, with his; this I think is work enough for their Astronomers; and Nature hath been so kind to conceal from 'em the rest of the Universe. Do you think it a favour then, says she? Yes, certainly, said I, for there are sixteen Planets in this great Vortex: Nature saves us the trouble of studying the Motions of 'em all, and shows us but seven, which I think is very obliging, tho' we know not how to value the kindness, for we have recover'd the other nine which were hid from us, and so render'd the Science of Astronomy much more difficult than Nature design'd it.</P058>

explanations: The metaphor in the French about the mutual curiosity of planets using 'Lunettes d'approche' (spyglasses) is shifted in tone with the addition of 'like two files of Musqueteers' in the English, introducing a militaristic connotation absent in the original, thus changing the flavor of the metaphor and moving away from the tone of refined scientific curiosity.

The French expresses that philosophers might be prosecuted ('on y a fait le procés à des Philosophes') due to our own actions (possible allusion to Galileo, etc.), whereas the English depersonalizes this and translates it as mere ridicule or prosecution simply for the idea, omitting the possibly self-critical original nuance of human responsibility in punishing unorthodox thinkers.

The English introduces 'Sir Francis Drake and Columbus' by name, which does not exist in the original; the French speaks generally of their 'Christophe Colombs' (Columbuses) as explorers on Jupiter, not alluding to Drake. This shifts the focus and adds an Anglo-centric frame.

The English splits the original idea ('elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, assurément leurs Christophe Colombs ne sauroient manquer d'employ') and reframes it as not yet having discovered the hundredth part, omitting specifically that their 'Columbuses' would be fully employed. The individualized explorer's continuous employment due to planetary size is glossed over.

The English renders the lack of knowledge of 'reputation' (de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples) as 'they have not yet discover'd the hundredth part of their Planet', omitting explicit reference to social interaction and reputation among peoples, thus flattening a subtle point about distance and unfamiliarity among Jupiter's inhabitants.

In the French, Nature is given agency with intentional 'bonté' (kindness), 'a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers' suggests thoughtful withholding. The English softens it to 'Nature hath been so kind', retaining the sense but weakening the agency, losing the allusion to a deliberate act of mercy or protection.

The English translation paraphrases the French sense of punishment for discovering too many planets ('aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.') as simply making Astronomy 'much more difficult than Nature design’d it', omitting the original notion of being 'punished' for our curiosity and effort. This shifts the philosophical tone from moralism to mere technicality.

chunks.source_manual: <P077>Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, répliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraîchement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nôtres, & que par consequent il a <IIM>des Pays</IIM>, où une seule nuit dure quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui êtant assez élevé pour être hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil <RW>dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point</RW>.</P077>
chunks.target_manual: <P059>If there are sixteen Planets, says she, Saturn must have five Moons. 'Tis very true, said I, and two of these five, are but lately discover'd; but there is somewhat that is more remarkable, since his Year is thirty of ours, there are consequently in him some Countreys, where their Night is fifteen years long; and what can you imagine Nature hath invented to give light, during so dreadful a Night? Why, she hath not only given Saturn five Moons, but she hath encompass'd him round with a great Circle or Ring, the which being plac'd beyond the reach of the shadow which the Body of that Planet casts, reflects the light of the Sun continually on those places where they cannot see the Sun at all.</P059>
source_segments: elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui êtant assez élevé pour être hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point.
target_segments: she hath encompass'd him round with a great Circle or Ring, the which being plac'd beyond the reach of the shadow which the Body of that Planet casts, reflects the light of the Sun continually on those places where they cannot see the Sun at all.
explanations: In the French, Fontenelle explains that the ring is 'assez élevé pour être hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete' (high enough to be outside the shadow of the planet's body), which underscores the scientific precision that the ring remains illuminated and thus can reflect light even during Saturn's long nights. The English translation simplifies this to 'plac'd beyond the reach of the shadow which the Body of that Planet casts,' which diminishes the emphasis on the ring’s elevation and continuous illumination. This subtle shift reduces the scientific nuance and could fail to properly convey the marvel and intent of nature as described in the Enlightenment context of rational design.

chunks.source_manual: <P078>En verité, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, <IIM>de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-même avec étonnement</IIM>, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroît bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Etres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas êté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'êtoit pas la peine d'en donner à Vénus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mêmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a <IIM>point de Lune</IIM>. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne savons pas. Vous avez veu des <SC>Phosphores</SC>, de ces matières liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. <SC>Peut-être Mars a-t-il</SC> de grands Rochers fort élevés, qui sont des <SC>Phosphores</SC> naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumière qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sauriez rier que ce ne fût un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'allumer de toutes parts dé que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous savez encore qu'il y a en Amérique des Oiseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que savons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oiseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous côtés, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?</P078>
chunks.target_manual: <P060>I protest, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, this is very surprizing, and yet all is contriv'd in such great order, that it is impossible not to think but Nature took time to consider the necessities of all animate Beings, and that the disposing of these Moons was not a work of Chance, for they are only divided among those Planets which are farthest distant from the Sun, the Earth, Jupiter, Saturn; indeed it was not worth while to give any to Mercury or Venus, they have too much light already; and they account their nights (as short as they are) a greater blessing than their day. But pray, why has not Mars a Moon too? It seems he has none, tho' he is much further than the Earth from the Sun. It is very true, said I; no doubt but he hath other helps, tho' we do not know 'em: You have seen the Phosphorus, both liquid and dry, how it receives and imbibes the rays of the Sun, and what a great light it will cast in a dark Place: Perhaps Mars hath many great high Rocks, which are so many natural Phosphorus's, which in the day take in a certain provision of light, and return it again at night. What think you, Madam, is it not very pleasant when the Sun is down to see those lighted Rocks, like so many Illuminations at a Birth day night? Besides, there is a kind of Bird in America, that yields such a light, you may read by it in the darkest night; and who knows but Mars may have great flocks of these Birds, that as soon as it is night, disperse themselves into all parts, and spread from their wings another day.</P060>

explanations: Translation of 'la Marquise' as 'the Countess' is a clear manipulation. Fontenelle’s original character is a marquise, not a countess; shifting the title changes both the specificity of the social rank and cultural resonance for English readers, potentially affecting the perceived status and connotations of the interlocutor.

The English adds 'it is impossible not to think but Nature took time to consider the necessities of all animate Beings', which shifts from the original, which more modestly observes that it seems Nature had the needs of some living beings in view (quelques Etres vivans), to a much broader assertion about all animate beings, thus exaggerating the universality of Nature's providence.

The phrase 'the disposing of these Moons was not a work of Chance' introduces more agency and deliberateness than the French 'n'a pas été faite au hazard' (not done by chance), which is softer; the translation amplifies purposeful planning, slightly intensifying the natural philosophy argument.

Reordering and rephrasing 'pour they are only divided among those Planets which are farthest distant from the Sun, the Earth, Jupiter, Saturn' removes the French’s explicit listing order and omits 'qu'aux' (only to), potentially weakening the sense of selective distribution and the unique group with moons.

The English omits 'ce n'êtoit pas la peine d'en donner à...' (it was not worth bothering to give them...) and changes the phrasing to 'they account their nights (as short as they are) a greater blessing than their day,' which not only alters the tone (removing some of the dry wit found in the French about 'not bothering') but also changes the connotation: the French implies that for Venus and Mercury, Nature did not see the point in giving moons, while English stresses the subjective appreciation of the inhabitants, reducing the observation’s original rational tone.

The English breaks the French’s reflective interruption ('attendez'/'wait!'), then paraphrases rather than translates 'il me semble que Mars...n'a point de Lune', introducing direct address and question format: 'But pray, why has not Mars a Moon too? It seems he has none...'. This makes the dialogue more confrontational and inquisitive than the original’s self-reflective tone, thereby shifting narrative attitude.

The English adds 'It is very true, said I; no doubt but he hath other helps, tho' we do not know 'em:' where the French is more philosophical and vague ('il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne savons pas'), making the English more pragmatic and implying certainty about unknown 'helps', whereas the French is speculative about Mars’s resources for its nights.

The reference 'You have seen the Phosphorus, both liquid and dry, how it receives and imbibes the rays of the Sun...' omits that the French is general ('des Phosphores, de ces matières liquides ou sèches') and the process, 'qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent', is paraphrased rather than translated: the translation flattens the step-by-step process of light absorption for a more general description, losing some of the detail and explanatory nuance of the original.

The English 'in the day take in a certain provision of light, and return it again at night' translates the action generically, but omits the French emphasis on the rocks as 'de grands Rochers fort élevés' (very great, tall rocks) and as 'Phosphores naturels' and 'provision de lumière qu'ils rendent', which stresses the natural, spectacular aspect and accumulation/return of light. The translation downplays the remarkable, almost magical effect described in the French.

The comparison in 'What think you, Madam, is it not very pleasant when the Sun is down to see those lighted Rocks, like so many Illuminations at a Birth day night?' omits the French's reference to 'illuminations magnifiques' and introduces 'a Birth day night' (i.e., birthday celebration), an anachronistic and domesticated image absent from the original. The French focuses on the natural spectacle’s magnificence, not a party analogy, changing the tone from awe to festive familiarity for English readers.

The English simplifies the luminous birds passage ('a kind of Bird in America... that yields such a light, you may read by it... Mars may have great flocks of these Birds') and specifically attributes the light to the birds' 'wings', a detail absent in the French, which simply says 'répandre un nouveau jour' (spread a new day). The translation changes how the effect is imagined and subtly naturalizes the luminous property (from 'birds in the darkness' in French, to 'birds spreading light from their wings' in English), shifting the marvel described.

chunks.source_manual: <P079>Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oiseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'être joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse êté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fût point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vraiment, répliquay-je, si <LS><IIM>vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites</IIM></LS>, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de même pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous êtions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos têtes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demiy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horizon, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroît une Habitation trop irregulière. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'êtoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échappées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez misérables. Il leur donne la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans le Groënland, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.</P079>
chunks.target_manual: <P061>I am not at all contented, says she, with your Rocks, or your Birds; 'tis a pretty fancy indeed, but 'tis a sign that there should be Moons in Mars, since Nature hath given so many to Saturn, and Jupiter; and if all the other Worlds that are distant from the Sun, have Moons, why should Mars only be excepted? Ah, Madam, said I, when you are a little more dip'd in Philosophy, you will find exceptions in the very best Systemes; there are always some things that agree extream well, but then there are others that do not accord at all; those you must leave as you found 'em, if ever you intend to make an end: We will do so by Mars, if you please, and say no more of him; but return to Saturn. What do you think of his great Ring, in the form of a semy Circle, that reaches from one end of the Horizon to the other, which reflecting the light of the Sun, performs the office of a continual Moon. And must we not inhabit this Ring too, says she? I confess, said I, in the humour I am in, I could almost send Colonies every where; and yet I can't well plant any there, it seems so irregular an habitation; but for the five little Moons, they cannot chuse but be inhabited; tho' some think this Ring is a Circle of Moons, which follow close to one another, and have one equal Motion; and that the five little Moons fell out of this Circle; how many Worlds are there then in the <UP>Vortex of Saturn</UP>? But let it be how it will, the People in Saturn live very miserably: 'Tis true, this Ring gives light to 'em, but it must be a very poor one, when the Sun seems to 'em but a little pale Star, whose light and heat cannot but be very weak at so great a distance; they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet, and that they would expire with heat in our coldest Countreys.</P061>

explanations: The original French 'il faut des Lunes' means 'there ought to be moons' or 'moons are necessary', in a general sense, but the translation particularizes it to 'there should be Moons in Mars', making it specific to Mars, which narrows the universal philosophical argument and shifts its rhetorical intent.

The nuanced original contrasts elements that fit perfectly in a system and others wedged in as best as possible, or set aside in despair. The translation simplifies it to a dichotomy of things that 'agree' and things that 'do not accord at all', and omits the idea of forcibly making things fit, resulting in a loss of the epistemic modesty and rhetorical playfulness of the original, subtly flattening the philosophical register.

The phrase 'qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë' means 'which, reflecting the sunlight back to us, would serve as a continuous/moon', but the translation's 'performs the office of a continual Moon' personifies and institutionalizes the effect, potentially losing the poetic and imaginative nuance of how the ring would appear, thus subtly changing the connotation and poetic feel.

The original 'je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroît une Habitation trop irregulière' implies the speaker 'would not dare' to put inhabitants there, because it 'seems too irregular an abode'. The English reduces the hesitation to 'can't well plant any there', softening the avowed boldness and cautiousness, and loses the explicit metaphor of populating as a potentially daring speculative act, which is key in the philosophical experimentation tone.

The phrase about the ring being 'un Cercle de Lunes' and the little moons as 'échappées de ce grand Cercle' ('runaways from this great circle') is translated as 'the five little Moons fell out of this Circle', which loses the deliberate playfulness and personification of the moons as having 'escaped' or 'broken away', thereby dulling the speculative and imaginative aspect of the original scientific discourse.

The original French tempers Saturn's misery with the phrase 'avec le secours même de l'Anneau' ('even with the help of the Ring'), emphasizing that despite assistance, misery prevails. The English omits this, simply saying 'the People in Saturn live very miserably', which removes the contextual detail of the ring's insufficient help and subtly alters the philosophical resignation.

The original expresses that if the Saturnians were placed in Earth's coldest locales such as Greenland or Lapland, 'you would see them sweat in great drops and expire from heat', which is a witty reversal. The translation muddles this to 'they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet, and that they would expire with heat in our coldest Countreys', introducing an external authority ('they say'), shifting the metaphor ('Bagnio'), and obscuring the directness and humorous nature of the original's scenario.

chunks.source_manual: <P080>Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, au lieu que tan tôt vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, répliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extrémitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.</P080> <P081>Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde êtoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne savent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique <IIM>trop badin & trop folâtre</IIM>. <NCE></NCE>.</P081>
chunks.target_manual: <P062>You give me, says she, such an Idea of Saturn, that makes me shake with cold, and that of Mercury, puts me into a feaver. It cannot be otherwise, I reply'd, for the two Worlds, which are the extremities of this great Vortex, must be opposite in all things. They must then, says she, be very wise in Saturn, for you told me they were all Fools in Mercury. If they are not wise, said I, yet they have all the appearances of being very Flegmatick: They are People that know not what 'tis to laugh, they take a days time to answer the least question you can ask 'em; and are so very grave, that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him <NCE>a merry Andrew</NCE>.</P062>
source_segments: parmi eux, ils eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre
target_segments: were Cato living among 'em, they would think him a merry Andrew
explanations: The French 'ils eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre' (they would have found Cato of Utica too playful and too frolicsome) is translated as 'they would think him a merry Andrew' (a comic buffoon or clown). This choice not only changes the connotation but also inserts a distinctly English cultural reference, 'merry Andrew,' that trivializes the comparison and shifts the nature of the satire from one of relative decorum (finding Cato too lighthearted) to outright ridicule (seeing Cato as a clown). This manipulation may alter the reader’s perception of Fontenelle’s subtle irony.

chunks.source_manual: <P082>Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lents. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nôtre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extrémitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractère fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différents. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'être icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.</P082>
chunks.target_manual: <P063>It is odd to consider, says she, that the Inhabitants of Mercury are all life, and the Inhabitants of Saturn quite contrary; but among us, some are brisk, and some are dull; it is, I suppose, because our Earth is plac'd in the middle of the other Worlds, and so we participate of both extreams, there is no fix'd or determin'd Character; some are made like the Inhabitants of Mercury, some like those of Saturn; we are a mixture of the several kinds that are found in the rest of the Planets. Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea? Methinks it is pleasant to be compos'd of such a fantastical Assembly, that one would think we were collected out of different Worlds; we need not travel, when we see the other Worlds in Epitome at home.</P063>
source_segments: Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle.
J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différents.

Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea? Methinks it is pleasant to be compos'd of such a fantastical Assembly, that one would think we were collected out of different Worlds;
we need not travel, when we see the other Worlds in Epitome at home.
explanations: The French 'Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle.' ('An idea occurs to me, she said.') is translated as 'It is odd to consider, says she,' which replaces the personal process of inspiration or sudden thought with a generic, impersonal reflection, altering the immediacy and subjectivity of the Marquise's intervention.

The French 'J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je,' (I rather like this idea, I replied) is mistranslated as 'Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea? Methinks it is pleasant...' which invents a question and moves the approval of the idea to the Marquise rather than the narrator, altering the attribution of enthusiasm and subtly shifting tone and characterization.

The original 'A ce compte, il est assez commode d'être icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.' ('On that account, it's rather convenient to be here; one sees all the other worlds in summary here.') is translated as 'we need not travel, when we see the other Worlds in Epitome at home.' This translation adds the idea of not needing to travel and specifies 'at home,' shifting the implication from the general convenience of Earth's position to a parochial focus and omitting the philosophical nuance of observing summaries of all worlds.

chunks.source_manual: <P083>Du moins, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nôtre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grâce à la Nature d'être Homme, & non pas Bête, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moi je veux luy rendre grâce d'être sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grâce d'être jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & <UP></UP> belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vôtre Tourbillon, ou de la température de vôtre Pays.</P083>
chunks.target_manual: <P064>I am sure, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, we have one great convenience in the situation of our World; it is not so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Jupiter or Saturn; and our Country is so justly plac'd, that we have no excess either of Heat or Cold. I have heard of a Philosopher, who gave thanks to Nature that he was born a Man, and not a Beast, a Greek, and not a Barbarian; and for my part, I render thanks that I am seated in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in one of the most temperate Regions of that Planet. You have more reason, said I, to give thanks that you are Young, and not Old; that you are Young and Handsome, and not Young and Ugly; that you are Young, Handsome, and an English Woman, and not Young, Handsome, <UP>and a Spaniard</UP>, or an Italian; these are other guess Subjects for your thanks, than the Situation of your Vortex, or the Temperature of your Countrey.</P064>
source_segments: la Marquise
Françoise, & non pas jeune & belle Italienne
target_segments: the Countess
an English Woman, and not Young, Handsome, and a Spaniard, or an Italian
explanations: The translation changes 'la Marquise' (the Marquise) to 'the Countess', which alters the social rank and cultural context of the character. In French society, a Marquise would have different implications than a Countess, affecting the reader's perception of her status and character.

The original contrasts 'jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & belle Italienne' (young and beautiful Frenchwoman, and not young and beautiful Italian), but the English version renders this as 'Young, Handsome, and an English Woman, and not Young, Handsome, and a Spaniard, or an Italian.' This shifts the national identity being privileged from French to English and adds 'Spaniard,' which is not present in the original, thus manipulating the original's national-cultural reference and subtly anglicizing the narrative.

chunks.source_manual: <P084>Mon Dieu! répliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a été donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considérables, un goût qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, répliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez vu jusqu'icy.</P084>
chunks.target_manual: <P065>Pray Sir, says she, let me give thanks for all things, to the very Vortex in which I am planted: Our proportion of Happiness is so very small, that we should lose none, but improve continually what we have, and be grateful for every thing, tho' never so common or inconsiderable. If nothing but exquisite pleasure will serve us, we must wait a long time, and be sure to pay too dear for it at last. I wish, said I, that Philosophy was the pleasure you propose, that when you think of Vortex's, you would not forget an humble Servant of your Ladyships. I esteem it a pleasure, says she, while it diverts innocently, but no longer. I will engage for it till to morrow, I reply'd, for the fix'd Stars are beyond what you have yet seen.</P065>

target_segments: I wish, said I, that Philosophy was the pleasure you propose, that when you think of Vortex's, you would not forget an humble Servant of your Ladyships. I esteem it a pleasure, says she, while it diverts innocently, but no longer.
I will engage for it till to morrow, I reply'd, for the fix'd Stars are beyond what you have yet seen.
explanations: The exchange about promising to be content with the pleasures offered by the vortices and the narrator ('vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous') is replaced in the translation by a generalized wish that Philosophy were the pleasure proposed and a distancing answer about innocent diversion. The playful implication of choosing between vivid pleasures and the more constancy of the narrator and the 'tourbillons' is lost, as well as the Marquise’s (she) acceptance—conditional on Philosophy providing new pleasures—being omitted.

The narrator's assurance for tomorrow and teasing promise of showing fixed stars 'qui passent tout ce que vous avez vu jusqu'icy' (which surpass all that you have seen so far) is condensed to 'I will engage for it till to morrow...for the fix'd Stars are beyond what you have yet seen.' The implication of continuous novelty and escalating wonder ('qui passent tout ce que vous avez vu') is less vivid, shifting from a promise of ever greater pleasures to just being 'beyond what you have seen.' The cumulative sense of quite outstripping prior wonders is minimized.

chunks.source_manual: <P085>CINQUIEME SOIR. Que les étoiles fixes sont autant de Soleils, dont chacun éclaire un monde.</P085>
chunks.target_manual: <P066>The Fifth Evening.</P066>
source_segments: Que les étoiles fixes sont autant de Soleils, dont chacun éclaire un monde.
explanations: The French segment explicitly summarizes the content of the fifth evening: 'That the fixed stars are so many suns, each of which lights a world.' The English translation omits this summary entirely, thus removing an important conceptual introduction and guiding statement for the discussion. This shifts the reader's perception and reduces their understanding of the scope and purpose of the chapter.

chunks.source_manual: <P086><UP></UP>. La <IIM>Marquise</IIM> sentit une vraye impatience de savoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-être, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sauroient être moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuë, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumière, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuë</IIM> <UP></UP>; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette même distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumière, qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuë</IIM>, eût cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voilà donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.</P086>
chunks.target_manual: <P067>THE <IIM>Countess</IIM> was very impatient to know what would become of the fix'd Stars; are they inhabited, says she, as the Planets are, or are they not inhabited? What shall we do with 'em? You may soon guess, said I; the fix'd Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth than fifty millions of leagues; nay, if you anger an Astronomer, he will set 'em further. The distance from the Sun to the farthest Planet, is nothing in comparison of the distance from the Sun, or from the Earth, to the fix'd Stars, it is almost beyond Arithmetick. You see their light is bright and shining, and did they receive it from the Sun, it must needs be very weak after a passage of <NCE>fifty millions of leagues</NCE>; then judge how much it is wasted by reflection; for it comes back again as far to us; so that forwards and backwards, here are <NCE>an hundred millions of leagues</NCE> for it to pass; and it is impossible it should be so clear and strong as the light of a fix'd Star, which cannot but proceed from it self; so that in a word, all the fix'd Stars are so many Suns.</P067>
source_segments: La Marquise sentit une vraye impatience de savoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient.
Vous le devineriez peut-être, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je.
on ne prend pas la peine de la compter
Il seroit impossible qu'une lumière, qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois cinquante millions de lieuë, eût cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes.
lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils
target_segments: THE Countess was very impatient to know what would become of the fix'd Stars;
You may soon guess, said I;
it is almost beyond Arithmetick.
and it is impossible it should be so clear and strong as the light of a fix'd Star, which cannot but proceed from it self;
all the fix'd Stars are so many Suns.
explanations: The change from 'La Marquise' (the Marquise) to 'the Countess' substitutes the character’s title and may confuse the cultural and hierarchical setting of French aristocracy as depicted by Fontenelle, altering the literary and social context.

The French 'Vous le devineriez peut-être, si vous en aviez bien envie,' which gently teases the Marquise's curiosity, is flattened to 'You may soon guess,' omitting the playful conditional and the nuance that the Marquise might guess if she truly wished.

The idiom 'on ne prend pas la peine de la compter' suggests the distance is so vast that it's hardly worth calculating, but the translation exaggerates this to 'it is almost beyond Arithmetick,' intensifying the impossibility and subtly shifting the original's tone of pragmatic dismissal to one of mathematical impotence.

The phrase 'Il seroit impossible qu'une lumière, qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois cinquante millions de lieuë, eût cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes' uses contemplative, slightly speculative language about the impossibility of reflected light retaining its vividness, which the translation turns into an absolute: 'it is impossible it should be so clear and strong as the light of a fix'd Star, which cannot but proceed from it self'—adding the strong assertion 'cannot but proceed from itself' that subtly shifts the epistemological level from likely to certain.

The French 'lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils' ('luminous by themselves, and all, in a word, as many Suns') is rendered as 'all the fix'd Stars are so many Suns,' omitting the explicit assertion of self-luminosity (lumineuses par elles-mêmes), which is central to Fontenelle’s point about the stars and undermines the explanatory clarity of the Enlightenment project.

chunks.source_manual: <P087>Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nôtre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Notre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis- je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toi qui l'as nommé. <UP></UP>.</P087>
chunks.target_manual: <P068>I perceive, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, where you would carry me; you are going to tell me, that if the fix'd Stars are so many Suns, and our Sun the centre of a Vortex that turns round him, why may not every fix'd Star be the centre of a Vortex that turns round the fix'd Star? Our Sun enlightens the Planets; why may not every fix'd Star have Planets to which they give light? You have said it, <UP>I reply'd, and I will not contradict you</UP>.</P068>
source_segments: Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis- je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toi qui l'as nommé..
target_segments: You have said it, I reply'd, and I will not contradict you.
explanations: The translation omits the intertextual reference to Phedre and Enone, which is present in the French ('que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toi qui l'as nommé..'). This allusion enriches the literary and cultural resonance of the dialogue, and its removal diminishes the philosophical and literary depth, subtly manipulating the tone and sophistication of the original exchange.

chunks.source_manual: <P088>Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sais plus où je suis, <RW>je ne suis plus rien</RW>. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-être aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes & Tout cet espace immense qui comprend notre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes? <UP></UP>. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moi, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le ciel n'étoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles êtoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte <UP></UP>, en la partageant en mille & mille <RW>Tourbillons</RW>, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & assurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous côtés les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde.<UP></UP>.</P088>
chunks.target_manual: <P069>You have made the Universe so large, says she, that I know not where I am, or what will become of me; what is it all to be divided into heaps confusedly, one among another? Is every Star the centre of a Vortex, as big as ours? Is that vast space which comprehends our Sun and Planets, but an inconsiderable part of the Universe? and are there as many such spaces, as there are fix'd Stars? <UP>I protest it is dreadful. Dreadful, Madam, said I</UP>; I think it very pleasant, when the Heavens were a little blue Arch, stuck with Stars; methought the Universe was too strait and close, I was almost stifled for want of Air; but now it is enlarg'd in heigth and breadth, and a thousand and a thousand Vortex's taken in; I begin to breath with more freedom, and think the Universe to be incomparably <UP>more magnificent than it was before</UP>. Nature hath spar'd no cost, even to profuseness, and nothing can be so glorious, as to see such a prodigious number of Vortex's, whose several centres are possess'd by a particular Sun, which makes the Planets turn round it. The Inhabitants of a Planet of one of these innumerable Vortex's, see on all sides these luminous centres of the Vortex, with which they are encompass'd; but perhaps they do not see the Planets, who receiving but a faint light from their Sun, cannot send it beyond their own World.</P069>
source_segments: Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sais plus où je suis, je ne suis plus rien.
Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante.
La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle.
target_segments: You have made the Universe so large, says she, that I know not where I am, or what will become of me;
I protest it is dreadful.
Nature hath spar'd no cost, even to profuseness,
explanations: The French 'je ne suis plus rien' (I am no longer anything) expresses an existential diminishment and loss of self, but the translation omits this, instead using the more generic 'what will become of me,' which dilutes the original's sense of ontological uncertainty and insignificance.

The original lists three escalating emotional responses ('confond', 'trouble', 'épouvante': confounds, disturbs, frightens me), but the translation simplifies and condenses them to 'I protest it is dreadful,' which flattens the emotional nuance and intensity found in the source.

'La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle.' suggests that Nature has spared nothing in its creation, producing a richness entirely worthy of itself. The translation 'Nature hath spar'd no cost, even to profuseness,' changes the emphasis to a financial metaphor ('no cost') and loses the sense of the act being inherently worthy of Nature, thus erasing the original's stylistic flourish and celebration of Nature's own grandeur.

chunks.source_manual: <P089>Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de notre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; aprés eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les aperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous êtes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis & <IIM>Nous mêmes, à qui la même expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes</IIM>. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. <IIM>Assurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoît pas les Tourbillons</IIM>. <UP></UP>. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondrai: Ah! si vous saviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas su, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'êtoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fût dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eût-elle échappé à Aristote?) <UP></UP>. mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eût êté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eût pas pu conquerir. A plus forte raison lui eût-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eût connus en ce temps-là; c'eût eté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon votre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.</P089> <P090>C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle, en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez- moi franchement, votre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-même comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien tôt aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De même accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-même il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroît, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroît point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empêche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune êtoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nôtre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous êtes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grâce. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nôtre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.</P090>
chunks.target_manual: <P070>You present me with a kind of Perspective of so vast a length, that no Eye can reach to the end of it: I plainly see the Inhabitants of the Earth, and you have made me discover those that dwell in the Moon, and in other Planets of our Vortex; but these indeed I do not see so clearly as those of the Earth; after these, we come to the Inhabitants of the Planets which are in other Vortex's, but they are sunk into so great a depth, that tho' I do all I can to see them, yet <UP>I must confess</UP> I can hardly perceive 'em; by the expression you use in speaking of 'em, they seem to be almost annihilated; you ought then to call 'em the Inhabitants of one of those innumerable Vortex's: We our selves, for whom the same expression serves, must confess, that we scarce know where we are, in the midst of so many Worlds; for my own part, I begin to see the Earth so fearfully little, that I believe from henceforth, I shall never be concern'd at all for any thing: That we so eagerly desire to make our selves great, that we are always designing, always troubling and harassing our selves, is certainly because we are ignorant what these Vortex's are; but now I hope my new lights will in part justifie my laziness, and when any one reproaches me with my carelessness, I will answer, Ah did you but know what the fix'd Stars are! It was not fit, said I, that Alexander should know what they were; for a certain Author who maintains that the Moon is inhabited, very gravely tells us, that Aristotle, (from whom no truth could be long conceal'd) must necessarily be of an opinion, back'd with so much reason; but yet he would never acquaint Alexander with the secret, fearing he might run mad with despair, when he knew there was another World, which he could not conquer; with much more reason then was this mystery of Vortex's, and fix'd Stars kept secret in Alexander's time; for tho' they had been known in those days, yet a Man would have been a great Fool, to have said any thing of 'em to Alexander; it had been but an ill way of making his court to that ambitious Prince; for my part, I that know 'em, am not a little troubled to find my self not one jot the wiser for all the knowledge I have of 'em; the most they can do, according to your way of reasoning, is but to cure People of their ambition, and their unquiet restless humour, which are diseases I am not at all troubled with; I confess, I am guilty of so much weakness, as to be in love with what is beautiful; that's my distemper, and I am confident, the Vortex's can never cure it: what if the other Worlds render ours so very little? they cannot spoil fine Eyes, or a pretty Mouth; their value is still the same, in spite of all the Worlds that can possibly exist.</P070>
