explanations: The phrase 'Vous m'affligez' ('You distress me' or 'You make me sad') was rendered simply as 'You afflict me', losing the more intimate, emotional shading of the original, and omitting the tone of mild or gentle complaint in the Marquise's response.

The original 'de la pitié pour les Habitans d'une Comète' (to pity the inhabitants of a comet) is qualified and subtler, indicating the narrator addressing the Marquise's anticipated sentiment; in English, it becomes a broader generalization and lacks Fontenelle's nuance, downplaying the shift from pity to another kind of sympathy.

The English turns the French hope ('j'espère du moins') into certainty: 'I suppose you will think their Condition lamentable' is slightly more assertive and directive about the Marquise’s feelings, subtly directing the reader’s emotional response.

'Quoi? s'écria-t-elle, des Soleils s'éteignent?' is literally 'What? she exclaimed, suns go out?' The translation 'can Suns be put out?' introduces an agent and a modal doubt, shifting from a surprised exclamation to a rhetorical question about possibility.

In the French, 'Les Anciens ont vû dans le Ciel des Etoiles Fixes que nous n'y voyons plus.' exploits a sense of empirical loss and temporal passage; the English adds 'for People some thousand years ago', which is an interpretive addition, specifying a historical timescale not present in the original and thus shaping the sense of historical witness.

The question 'car que faire sans Soleil?' (for what to do without sun?) becomes 'for what can People do without a Sun?', which introduces the word 'People' and generalizes the question, subtly shifting the existential focus from a cosmic order to human agency.

The Marquise's direct plea to spare her the distressing thought ('N'y auroit-il pas moyen de me l'épargner?') is rendered as 'I would not if I could help it, let it come into my head.' This omits the dialogic, supplicatory quality, and converts a plea into a mere wish, weakening her role and voice.

The source cites 'de fort habiles Gens' ('very skillful people'), making it clear this is expert, contemporary opinion, whereas the translation summarises as 'the Opinion of Learned Astronomers', which may or may not correspond to Fontenelle’s intended vagueness (since he sometimes refers to philosophers or savants more generally and with a hint of irony/skepticism). Thus, some intended distance and ambiguity are lost.

'Autrement les demy Soleils ne peuvent pas subsister.' (Otherwise half Suns cannot exist.) becomes 'otherwise there could be no such thing as half Suns,’ which neutralizes the logical assertion of impossibility by making it more hypothetical and removes the tone of playful logic.

The source frames the question as a hypothetical and rational doubt about observed phenomena ('Mais que dirons nous'), while the English shifts subtly to a more emotional and concrete construction ('But what shall we say of Stars, which totally disappear') that forecloses some of the speculative openness.

The French presents user agency and philosophical debate ('Je feray encore un effort en votre faveur') before offering the alternative explanation; the English, 'However I will try once more what I can do in favour of your Opinion,' renders this as a mere concession, losing some of the playful, teasing dynamic.

The French phrase 'Il est vray que la plus grande partie des Etoiles Fixes n'ont pas ce mouvement...' refers to a general astronomical condition; the English introduces the notion 'because at other times they might return again nearer to us,' which slightly shifts the logical structure and temporal assumptions in the chain of reasoning.

The French's 'petits Tourbillons plus légers & plus agiles qui se glissent entre les autres, & font de certains tours, au bout desquels ils reviennent, tandis que le gros des Tourbillons demeure immobile;' is rendered as 'none but the Little, Light, and most Active Vortex's which slip between the others make certain voyages, after which they return again, while the main body of Vortex's remain unmov'd.' The English adds 'make certain voyages', inserting an anthropomorphic, intentional idea not present in the original, and loses the direct contrast (glissement/immobile).

In the translation, the summary 'Half Suns would appear again at their set and regulated time. Now Madam, boldly declare your Opinion; Must not these Stars...' merges and reorders two French sentences and converts a progression into a forced rhetorical dilemma, which reduces the speculative play of possibilities expressed by Fontenelle.

'Comment un Soleil peut-il s'obscurcir & s'éteindre, dit la Marquise, luy qui est en lui-même une source de lumière?' is rendered as 'How can a Sun said the Countess, be darkned, and quite extinguish'd, when it is in its own Nature a Fountain of Light?', which shifts the emphasis from a challenge to cosmic paradox to more ordinary disbelief and loses the unique voice of the Marquise’s original phrasing.

The specific instruction 'Le plus aisément du Monde, selon Descartes...' ('most easily in the world, according to Descartes') is changed to 'if Desc�rtes Opinion be true...' making it more hypothetical and less confident, and the explanation is condensed and less evocative of the original contemporary scientific debate, losing the lively sense of ongoing discourse with 'tout ce qu'il vous plaira.'

The French 'Nous l'avons déjà même échappée, dit-on. Le Soleil a été très pâle pendant des années entières...' is more nuanced in relating rumor and near-miss. The English, 'We have hitherto scap'd pretty well; but 'tis said, that the Sun for some whole years together hath look'd very pale; for Example, the year after Caesar's death;' omits 'dit-on' (it is said), introducing unqualified authority, and omits the conditional hypotheticals about universal consequences, reducing the drama.

The Marquise's joke about checking her own pallor versus the Sun's ('je crois qu'au lieu d'aller voir les matins à mon miroir si je ne suis point pâle, j'iray voir au Ciel si le Soleil ne l'est point luy même.') is recast: 'I believe, instead of going every morning to my Glass, to see how I look, I shall cast my Eyes up to Heaven, to see whether or no the Sun looks pale.' The translation removes the playful reference to the Marquise's beauty routine and sense of social consequence, flattening the lively interplay.

The resigned inquiry 'Mais enfin, dit-elle, il ne faut que du temps?' ('But in the end, she said, it's only a matter of time?') is rendered as 'Grant it, said she, yet 'tis but time that is required.' This shifts from a philosophical precipitation to an acceptance, altering the speaker's attitude and the dialectical structure.

The French states 'dés qu'il y a du mouvement quelque part, ne vous y fiez point, il faut qu'il arrive des changements, soit lents, soit prompts, mais toûjours dans des temps proportionnez à l'effet.' The English omits the cautionary phrase 'ne vous y fiez point' (do not trust it), removing a note of warning/distrust in the stability of natural systems.

'Les Anciens êtaient plaisants de s'imaginer que les Corps celestes étoient de nature à ne changer jamais, parce qu'ils ne les avoient pas encore vû changer. Avoient-ils eu le loisir de s'en assurer par l'expérience? Les Anciens étoient jeunes auprés de nous.' is condensed in English to 'The Ancients were pleasant Gentlemen … they were Boys in comparison of us.' This removes specific references to 'experience' and the key theme: the limitations of historical observation over time, thus muting Fontenelle's argument about the relativity of experience and knowledge.

Fontenelle’s allegory is slightly moralistic and complex: 'Si les Roses qui ne durent qu'un jour faisoient des Histoires...' etc. The English passage interprets and amplifies the fable, inserting commentary like 'Would not these Roses, Madam, talk very foolishly? and yet there would be more reason in their discourse, than there was in what the Ancients said concerning celestial Bodies;' which is more didactic and opinionated than Fontenelle’s intended gentle irony toward scientific humility.

The French, 'il faudroit qu'une chose eût passé bien des âges d'homme mis à bout pour commencer à donner quelque signe d'immortalité.' is rendered as 'To have lasted many Ages of Men, one after another, is no sign of Immortality.' The emphasis on the skeptical patience ('pour commencer à donner quelque signe') is replaced with a bald assertion, losing Fontenelle's careful gradation of epistemological caution.

'Je ne leur ferois seulement pas l'honneur de les comparer à ce Jardinier...' is translated as 'I will not do 'em so much honour, as to ompare 'em to the Gardiner that lived so much longer than the Roses:', missing the intended tongue-in-cheek humility (Marquise denies cosmic things even the honor of the gardener's endurance), thus reducing the philosophical wit of comparison.

The French 'il faut que l'espce se repare' (the species must repair itself/restock) is rendered as 'because every species must preserve it self', which evokes much more the idea of self-preservation or self-regulation (possibly with Darwinian connotations), whereas the French is more passive and does not imply species agency.

Fontenelle has the narrator gently reassure: 'Il n'est pas à craindre qu'elle perisse, répondis-je.' ('It is not to be feared that it [the species] will perish.') Replaced with the more forceful 'No species, Madam, said I, can totally perish;', which universalizes the specific philosophical argument, changing the tone.

'Je crois aisément que tout cela peut être, mais je croy aussi que l'Univers peut avoir êté fait de sorte qu'il s'y formera de temps en temps des Soleils nouveaux.' ('I easily believe all that may be, but also believe that the Universe may have been made so that new suns will form from time to time.') The translation, 'If I should think all this possible, yet I likewise believe that the Universe may be framed in such a manner, that from time to time it may produce new Suns;'—there is a subtle but cumulative dilution of Fontenelle’s personal opinion and the play between subjective possibility and cosmic mechanism.

The phrase 'N'auroit-elle le secret que de faire naître & mourir des herbes ou des plantes par une revolution continuelle?' ('Would Nature have only the secret of making plants and herbs be born and die by a continual revolution?') is paraphrased as 'Can we think that wise Nature knows no more than the secret of making Herbs and Plants live and die by a continual revolution?', shifting the original’s playful pseudo-question about Nature’s capacity toward a more rhetorical and defensive formulation.

The French 'je trouve à present les Mondes, les Cieux, & les Corps celestes si sujets au changement, que m'en voila tout à fait revenuë.' is rendered as 'I now find, says the Countess, the Worlds, the Heaven, and celestial Bodies so subject to change, that I am come to my self again.' The English omits the emphasis on reversal and the emotional coloring of 'revenuë', diminishing the transformative aspect of the Marquise's admission.

Fontenelle's conclusion: 'n'en parlons plus, aussi bien vous voila arrivée à la derniere voûte des Cieux; & pour vous dire s'il y a encore des Etoiles au-delà, il faudroit être plus habile que je ne suis. Mettez-y encore des Mondes, n'y en mettez pas, cela dépend de vous. C'est proprement l'Empire des Philosophes que ces grands païs invisibles qui peuvent être ou n'être pas si on veut, ou être tels que l'on veut, il me suffit d'avoir mené vôtre esprit aussi loin que vont vos yeux.' is changed to "let us say no more of these Matters. We are arrived at the very roof and top of all the Heavens; and to tell you whether there be any Stars beyond it, you must have an abler Man than I am; you may place Worlds there, or no Worlds, as you please: 'Tis the Philosopher's Empire to describe those vast invisible Countries, which are, and are not, or are such as he pleases to make 'em: It is enough for me, to have carried your mind as far as you can see with your Eyes." The translation gives an oddly possessive tone to "the Philosopher's Empire", omits the play with the reader's agency ('cela dépend de vous'), and therefore diminishes the shared imaginative invitation and the work’s inclusive Enlightenment spirit.

chunks.source_manual: <P105>Quoi, s'écria-t-elle, j'ay dans la tête tout le systeme de l'Univers! Je suis savante! Oüy, répliquay-je, vous l'êtes assez raisonnablement, & vous l'êtes avec la commodité de pouvoir ne rien croire de tout ce que je vous ay dit dés que l'envie vous en prendra. Je vous demande seulement pour recompense de mes peines de ne voir jamais le Soleil, ny le Ciel, ny les Etoiles, sans songer à moy.</P105>
chunks.target_manual: <P084>Well, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I have now in my Head, the System of the Universe: How learned am I become? Indeed, Madam, said I, you are pretty knowing, and you are so with the advantage of believing, or not believing any thing I have said: For all my pains, I only beg this favour, that when ever you see the Sun, the Heaven, or the Stars, you will think of me.</P084>

target_segments: you are pretty knowing
with the advantage of believing, or not believing any thing I have said
explanations: The French phrase 'vous l'êtes assez raisonnablement' implies a moderate, reasonable degree of knowledge ('you are reasonably learned'), whereas the translation 'you are pretty knowing' carries a slightly more colloquial and casual tone, losing the original nuance of modest, balanced intellectual achievement.

The French 'avec la commodité de pouvoir ne rien croire de tout ce que je vous ay dit dés que l'envie vous en prendra' highlights the convenience or ease of being able to not believe anything at all I have told you whenever you wish. The translation 'with the advantage of believing, or not believing any thing I have said' generalizes this, omitting the specific aspect of convenience and the whimsical aspect of 'whenever you wish,' thus subtly shifting the tone from playful skepticism to a more static, binary choice.
